channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Breaking ice, and helicopter drops: winning photos of working scientists
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01181-7

Nature’s annual photography competition attracted stunning images from around the world, including two very different shots featuring the Polarstern research vessel.
item.dc:title: Breaking ice, and helicopter drops: winning photos of working scientists
item.dc:creator: Jack Leeming

item.title: European ruling linking climate change to human rights could be a game changer — here’s how
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01177-3

The European Court of Human Rights’ judgment in a Swiss case cements the concept that climate inaction violates human rights — responsible nations around the world will take heed.
item.dc:title: European ruling linking climate change to human rights could be a game changer — here’s how
item.dc:creator: Charlotte E. Blattner

item.title: Lethal AI weapons are here: how can we control them?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01029-0

Autonomous weapons guided by artificial intelligence are already in use. Researchers, legal experts and ethicists are struggling with what should be allowed on the battlefield.
item.dc:title: Lethal AI weapons are here: how can we control them?
item.dc:creator: David Adam

item.title: How ground glass might save crops from drought on a Caribbean island
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01182-6

In Grenada, public-health researcher Lindonne Telesford tests a soil additive made from recycled glass that could help farmers adapt to climate change.
item.dc:title: How ground glass might save crops from drought on a Caribbean island
item.dc:creator: Kendall Powell

item.title: Dozens of genes are linked to post-traumatic stress disorder
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01147-9

Findings underscore that genetic factors contribute to development of the condition after a traumatic incident.
item.dc:title: Dozens of genes are linked to post-traumatic stress disorder

item.title: Multimodal cell atlas of the ageing human skeletal muscle
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07348-6

The Human Muscle Ageing Cell Atlas provides a series of integrated cellular and molecular explanations for sarcopenia and frailty development in advanced ages.
item.dc:title: Multimodal cell atlas of the ageing human skeletal muscle

item.title: How to freeze a memory: putting worms on ice stops them forgetting
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01130-4

The model organism Caenorhabditis elegans is quick to forget a notable odour — unless it is chilled or given lithium.
item.dc:title: How to freeze a memory: putting worms on ice stops them forgetting
item.dc:creator: Julian Nowogrodzki

item.title: Your perception of time is skewed by what you see
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01169-3

Features of a scene such as size and clutter can affect the brain’s sense of how much time has passed while observing it.
item.dc:title: Your perception of time is skewed by what you see
item.dc:creator: Lilly Tozer

item.title: How volcanoes shaped our planet — and why we need to be ready for the next big eruption
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01179-1

The world should learn from past disasters and prepare for the effects of future, inevitable volcanic catastrophes, a wide-reaching book teaches us.
item.dc:title: How volcanoes shaped our planet — and why we need to be ready for the next big eruption
item.dc:creator: Heather Handley

item.title: Will AI accelerate or delay the race to net-zero emissions?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01137-x

As artificial intelligence transforms the global economy, researchers need to explore scenarios to assess how it can help, rather than harm, the climate.
item.dc:title: Will AI accelerate or delay the race to net-zero emissions?
item.dc:creator: Amy Luers
Jonathan Koomey
Eric Masanet
Owen Gaffney
Felix Creutzig
Juan Lavista Ferres
Eric Horvitz

item.title: Living on Mars would probably suck — here's why
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01158-6

Kelly and Zach Weinersmith join us to discuss their book A City on Mars: Can We Settle Space, Should We Settle Space, and Have We Really Thought This Through?
item.dc:title: Living on Mars would probably suck — here's why
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Thompson

item.title: Detectors deep in South Pole ice pin down elusive tau neutrino
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01073-w

Antarctic observatory gathers the first clear evidence of mysterious subatomic particles from space.
item.dc:title: Detectors deep in South Pole ice pin down elusive tau neutrino

item.title: Dogwhistles, drilling and the roots of Western civilization: Books in brief
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01160-y

Andrew Robinson reviews five of the best science picks.
item.dc:title: Dogwhistles, drilling and the roots of Western civilization: Books in brief
item.dc:creator: Andrew Robinson

item.title: Australia’s Great Barrier Reef is ‘transforming’ because of repeated coral bleaching
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01151-z

The coral reef is experiencing its worst mass bleaching event on record — and warming waters brought on by climate change are to blame.
item.dc:title: Australia’s Great Barrier Reef is ‘transforming’ because of repeated coral bleaching
item.dc:creator: Bianca Nogrady

item.title: Do insects have an inner life? Animal consciousness needs a rethink
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01144-y

A declaration signed by dozens of scientists says there is ‘a realistic possibility’ for elements of consciousness in reptiles, insects and molluscs.
item.dc:title: Do insects have an inner life? Animal consciousness needs a rethink
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.title: Londoners see what a scientist looks like up close in 50 photographs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01156-8

Nature’s Where I Work images are being exhibited in the UK capital until June.
item.dc:title: Londoners see what a scientist looks like up close in 50 photographs
item.dc:creator: Jack Leeming

item.title: Why queasiness kills hunger: brain circuit identified
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01037-0

Feelings of hunger, nausea and fullness seem to be governed by separate brain circuits, finds a study in mice.
item.dc:title: Why queasiness kills hunger: brain circuit identified
item.dc:creator: Gillian Dohrn

item.title: Burnt remains of Maya royalty mark a dramatic power shift
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01075-8

Finds in pyramid at Guatemalan site suggest that remains were disinterred and desecrated in a public ritual.
item.dc:title: Burnt remains of Maya royalty mark a dramatic power shift

item.title: Violent volcanoes have wracked Jupiter’s moon Io for billions of years
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01138-w

Understanding the volcanic moon’s history could offer fresh insights into conditions on early Earth.
item.dc:title: Violent volcanoes have wracked Jupiter’s moon Io for billions of years
item.dc:creator: Sarah Wild

item.title: Meet ‘goldene’: this gilded cousin of graphene is also one atom thick
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01118-0

Sheets of gold might find use as catalysts, or in light-sensing devices.
item.dc:title: Meet ‘goldene’: this gilded cousin of graphene is also one atom thick
item.dc:creator: Mark Peplow

item.title: AI’s keen diagnostic eye
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01132-2

Powered by deep-learning algorithms, artificial intelligence systems could replace agents such as chemicals currently used to augment medical scans.
item.dc:title: AI’s keen diagnostic eye
item.dc:creator: Neil Savage

item.title: Nearly half of China’s major cities are sinking — some ‘rapidly’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01149-7

Tens of millions of people in the country’s coastal lands might find their homes below sea level by 2120 owing to sinking and sea-level rise.
item.dc:title: Nearly half of China’s major cities are sinking — some ‘rapidly’
item.dc:creator: Xiaoying You

item.title: This water bottle purifies your drink with energy from your steps
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01074-9

Static electricity generated by the foot striking the ground can be captured to kill pathogens.
item.dc:title: This water bottle purifies your drink with energy from your steps

item.title: AI and robotics demystify the workings of a fly's wing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01122-4

New research unveils the workings of one of the most complex bio-mechanical structures in the natural world
item.dc:title: AI and robotics demystify the workings of a fly's wing
item.dc:creator: Dan Fox

item.title: DNA glycosylases provide antiviral defence in prokaryotes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07329-9

A screen utilizing an environmental DNA library in Escherichia coli is used to identify Brig1, a previously unknown anti-phage defence system with homologues across distinct clades of bacteria.
item.dc:title: DNA glycosylases provide antiviral defence in prokaryotes
item.dc:creator: Amer A. Hossain

item.title: Hybrid speciation driven by multilocus introgression of ecological traits
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07263-w

Genomic studies of Heliconius butterflies provide evidence that Heliconius elevatus is a hybrid species, and that its speciation was driven by introgression of traits from Heliconius melpomene into the other parent, an ancestor of Heliconius pardalinus.
item.dc:title: Hybrid speciation driven by multilocus introgression of ecological traits

item.title: Methane emission from a cool brown dwarf
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07190-w

Methane emission from a very cool brown dwarf, perhaps arising from an aurora, has been detected in James Webb Space Telescope observations.
item.dc:title: Methane emission from a cool brown dwarf

item.title: Stepwise activation of a metabotropic glutamate receptor
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07327-x

We propose a model for a sequential, multistep activation mechanism of metabotropic glutamate receptor subtype 5, including a series of structures in lipid nanodiscs, from inactive to fully active, with agonist-bound intermediate states.
item.dc:title: Stepwise activation of a metabotropic glutamate receptor
item.dc:creator: Kaavya Krishna Kumar
Haoqing Wang
Chris Habrian

Brian K. Kobilka

item.title: The economic commitment of climate change
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07219-0

Analysis of projected sub-national damages from temperature and precipitation show an income reduction of 19% of the world economy within the next 26 years independent of future emission choices.
item.dc:title: The economic commitment of climate change
item.dc:creator: Maximilian Kotz
Anders Levermann
Leonie Wenz

item.title: Neural crest origin of sympathetic neurons at the dawn of vertebrates
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07297-0

Challenging the belief that sympathetic ganglia are an innovation of jawed vertebrates, a study reports the presence of sympathetic neurons in an extant jawless vertebrate, the sea lamprey Petromyzon marinus.
item.dc:title: Neural crest origin of sympathetic neurons at the dawn of vertebrates
item.dc:creator: Brittany M. Edens
Jan Stundl
Hugo A. Urrutia
Marianne E. Bronner

item.title: Refining the impact of genetic evidence on clinical success
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07316-0

Human genetic evidence increases the success rate of drugs from clinical development to approval but we are still far from reaching peak genetic insights to aid the discovery of targets for more effective drugs.
item.dc:title: Refining the impact of genetic evidence on clinical success
item.dc:creator: Eric Vallabh Minikel
Jeffery L. Painter
Coco Chengliang Dong
Matthew R. Nelson

item.title: Seismological evidence for a multifault network at the subduction interface
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07245-y

Using observations of double-difference relocated earthquakes in a local three-dimensional velocity model for Ecuador, a detailed image of seismicity is created, forming the base for more realistic models of earthquake rupture, slip and hazard in subduction zones.
item.dc:title: Seismological evidence for a multifault network at the subduction interface
item.dc:creator: Caroline Chalumeau
Hans Agurto-Detzel
Andreas Rietbrock
Michael Frietsch
Onno Oncken
Monica Segovia
Audrey Galve

item.title: Biogeographic response of marine plankton to Cenozoic environmental changes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07337-9

Analysis of a global dataset reveals spatiotemporal patterns of marine plankton and their biogeographical responses during climatic and environmental changes across the Cenozoic era.
item.dc:title: Biogeographic response of marine plankton to Cenozoic environmental changes
item.dc:creator: Anshuman Swain
Adam Woodhouse
William F. Fagan
Andrew J. Fraass
Christopher M. Lowery

item.title: Control of working memory by phase–amplitude coupling of human hippocampal neurons
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07309-z

Hippocampal theta–gamma phase–amplitude coupling integrates cognitive control and working memory storage across brain areas in humans.
item.dc:title: Control of working memory by phase–amplitude coupling of human hippocampal neurons
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Daume
Jan Kamiński

item.title: Network-level encoding of local neurotransmitters in cortical astrocytes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07311-5

A study investigates subcellular, single-cell and network-level comunication within the astrocyte network in response to the two major neurotransmitter inputs.
item.dc:title: Network-level encoding of local neurotransmitters in cortical astrocytes
item.dc:creator: Michelle K. Cahill
Max Collard
Vincent Tse
Michael E. Reitman
Roberto Etchenique
Christoph Kirst
Kira E. Poskanzer

item.title: Corner- and edge-mode enhancement of near-field radiative heat transfer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07279-2

Near-field radiative heat transfer between two coplanar silicon carbide membranes in close proximity is enhanced by the electromagnetic corner and edge modes.
item.dc:title: Corner- and edge-mode enhancement of near-field radiative heat transfer
item.dc:creator: Lei Tang
Lívia M. Corrêa
Mathieu Francoeur
Chris Dames

item.title: Brain endothelial GSDMD activation mediates inflammatory BBB breakdown
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07314-2

Lipopolysaccharide-induced breakdown of the blood–brain barrier requires activation of GSDMD-mediated plasma membrane permeabilization and pyroptosis in brain endothelial cells.
item.dc:title: Brain endothelial GSDMD activation mediates inflammatory BBB breakdown
item.dc:creator: Chao Wei
Wei Jiang

item.title: Stripped-envelope supernova light curves argue for central engine activity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07262-x

Analysis of the energy budget of a sample of 54 well-observed stripped-envelope supernovae of all sub-types shows statistically significant, largely model-independent, observational evidence for a non-radioactive power source in most of them.
item.dc:title: Stripped-envelope supernova light curves argue for central engine activity
item.dc:creator: Ósmar Rodríguez
Ehud Nakar
Dan Maoz

item.title: Environmental drivers of increased ecosystem respiration in a warming tundra
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07274-7

Datasets from in situ warming experiments across 28 arctic and alpine tundra sites covering  a span of less than 1 year up to 25 years show the importance of local soil conditions and warming-induced changes therein for future climatic impacts on ecosystem respiration.
item.dc:title: Environmental drivers of increased ecosystem respiration in a warming tundra

item.title: Machine learning reveals the control mechanics of an insect wing hinge
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07293-4

Measurements of fly muscle activity using a genetically encoded calcium indicator and high-speed imaging of wing movement were used to construct a model of the insect wing hinge and the role of steering muscles in flight control.
item.dc:title: Machine learning reveals the control mechanics of an insect wing hinge
item.dc:creator: Johan M. Melis
Igor Siwanowicz
Michael H. Dickinson

item.title: Digital colloid-enhanced Raman spectroscopy by single-molecule counting
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07218-1

Research published in Nature shows that surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy carried out with colloids can quantify a range of molecules down to concentrations at the femtomolar level.
item.dc:title: Digital colloid-enhanced Raman spectroscopy by single-molecule counting
item.dc:creator: Xinyuan Bi
Daniel M. Czajkowsky
Zhifeng Shao
Jian Ye

item.title: Streptomyces umbrella toxin particles block hyphal growth of competing species
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07298-z

Streptomyces are discovered to produce antibacterial protein complexes that selectively inhibit the hyphal growth of related species, a function distinct from that of the small-molecule antibiotics they are known for.
item.dc:title: Streptomyces umbrella toxin particles block hyphal growth of competing species
item.dc:creator: Qinqin Zhao
Savannah Bertolli
Young-Jun Park
Yongjun Tan

Joseph D. Mougous

item.title: Laser spectroscopy of triply charged <sup>229</sup>Th isomer for a nuclear clock
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07296-1

The trapping of triply charged 229mTh3+ is described and its nuclear decay half-life determined, showing useful properties for the development of a nuclear clock and applications in the search for new physics.
item.dc:title: Laser spectroscopy of triply charged <sup>229</sup>Th isomer for a nuclear clock
item.dc:creator: Atsushi Yamaguchi
Yudai Shigekawa
Hiromitsu Haba
Hidetoshi Kikunaga
Kenji Shirasaki
Michiharu Wada
Hidetoshi Katori

item.title: Promiscuous G-protein activation by the calcium-sensing receptor
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07331-1

Structures of the human calcium-sensing receptor can be bound into complex with G proteins from three different Gα subtypes while maintaining G-protein-binding specificity.
item.dc:title: Promiscuous G-protein activation by the calcium-sensing receptor
item.dc:creator: Hao Zuo
Jinseo Park
Aurel Frangaj
Jianxiang Ye
Guanqi Lu
Jamie J. Manning

Qing R. Fan

item.title: Control of neuronal excitation–inhibition balance by BMP–SMAD1 signalling
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07317-z

Signalling by the developmental morphogen BMP2 through the transcription factor SMAD1 has a key role in controlling the glutamatergic innervation of parvalbumin-expressing interneurons and maintaining the balance between excitation and inhibition in the mammalian cortex.
item.dc:title: Control of neuronal excitation–inhibition balance by BMP–SMAD1 signalling
item.dc:creator: Zeynep Okur
Nadia Schlauri
Vassilis Bitsikas
Myrto Panopoulou
Raul Ortiz
Michaela Schwaiger
Kajari Karmakar

Peter Scheiffele

item.title: Smoking bans are coming: what does the evidence say?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00472-3

Countries are cracking down on tobacco use and vaping — the laws could save thousands of lives and billions of dollars, say scientists.
item.dc:title: Smoking bans are coming: what does the evidence say?
item.dc:creator: Carissa Wong

item.title: Exploring the lung microbiome’s role in disease
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01123-3

Unusual microbial communities in a person’s lower airways could influence the onset and progression of lung cancer and other conditions, and might point the way to therapies.
item.dc:title: Exploring the lung microbiome’s role in disease
item.dc:creator: Anthony King

item.title: Dad always mows on summer Saturday mornings
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00920-0

A clear-cut success.
item.dc:title: Dad always mows on summer Saturday mornings
item.dc:creator: Beth Cato

item.title: Researchers want a ‘nutrition label’ for academic-paper facts
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01135-z

An ‘at a glance’ approach to publication details, such as journal acceptance rates and the number of peer reviewers, would promote transparency, scientists say.
item.dc:title: Researchers want a ‘nutrition label’ for academic-paper facts
item.dc:creator: Dalmeet Singh Chawla

item.title: We must protect the global plastics treaty from corporate interference
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01090-9

A United Nations-backed agreement to end plastic pollution is within reach — but only if scientists, civil society and businesses unite against powerful vested interests.
item.dc:title: We must protect the global plastics treaty from corporate interference
item.dc:creator: Martin Wagner

item.title: Deadly diseases and inflatable suits: how I found my niche in virology research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01098-1

Virologist Hulda Jónsdóttir studies some of the world’s most pathogenic viruses at the Spiez Laboratory in Switzerland.
item.dc:title: Deadly diseases and inflatable suits: how I found my niche in virology research
item.dc:creator: Nikki Forrester

item.title: Nanoparticle fix opens up tricky technique to forensic applications
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01015-6

A technique called surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy can detect tiny quantities of compounds in solution, but has been difficult to use for quantitative analysis. A digital approach involving nanoparticles suggests a way forward.
item.dc:title: Nanoparticle fix opens up tricky technique to forensic applications
item.dc:creator: Peter J. Vikesland

item.title: How young people benefit from Swiss apprenticeships
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01102-8

Computational biologist Jitao David Zhang says that the country’s vocational training programme teaches key work and life skills.
item.dc:title: How young people benefit from Swiss apprenticeships
item.dc:creator: Jitao David Zhang

item.title: Coupled neural activity controls working memory in humans
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00963-3

How does the human brain temporarily store information without losing track of it? Neuroscientists have discovered that neurons in the frontal and temporal lobes work together to hold information in working memory.
item.dc:title: Coupled neural activity controls working memory in humans
item.dc:creator: Ziv Williams

item.title: CERN’s impact goes way beyond tiny particles
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01100-w

A global effort to uncover the nature of the Universe has had resounding effects on scientists and society.
item.dc:title: CERN’s impact goes way beyond tiny particles
item.dc:creator: Nikki Forrester

item.title: UN plastics treaty: don’t let lobbyists drown out researchers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01089-2

Tackling plastic pollution needs scientists to be in the negotiating room at upcoming talks.
item.dc:title: UN plastics treaty: don’t let lobbyists drown out researchers

item.title: Canadian science gets biggest boost to PhD and postdoc pay in 20 years
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01124-2

Government budget includes more money for basic research and notable increases to postgraduate stipends.
item.dc:title: Canadian science gets biggest boost to PhD and postdoc pay in 20 years
item.dc:creator: Brian Owens

item.title: Humans and their livestock have sheltered in this Saudi Arabian cave for 10,000 years
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01131-3

Saudi herders have travelled the same routes for millennia, cave discovery suggests.
item.dc:title: Humans and their livestock have sheltered in this Saudi Arabian cave for 10,000 years
item.dc:creator: Gillian Dohrn

item.title: Keys, wallet, phone: the neuroscience behind working memory
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01136-y

Brain areas work in tandem to temporarily store important information, and an aurora on a cool brown dwarf.
item.dc:title: Keys, wallet, phone: the neuroscience behind working memory
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Thompson
Noah Baker

item.title: I dive for fish in the longest freshwater lake in the world
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01099-0

Biologist Carolin Sommer-Trembo describes her fascination for fish and why she enjoys doing science in Switzerland.
item.dc:title: I dive for fish in the longest freshwater lake in the world
item.dc:creator: Nikki Forrester

item.title: Bacteria deploy umbrella toxins against their competitors
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01016-5

Bacteria make protein toxins to compete with other bacteria in microbial communities. A study of a common soil bacterium has revealed a previously unknown type of antibacterial toxin that forms a striking umbrella-like structure.
item.dc:title: Bacteria deploy umbrella toxins against their competitors
item.dc:creator: Sarah J. Coulthurst

item.title: Surprise hybrid origins of a butterfly species
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00858-3

Mating between different species has often been considered an evolutionary dead end, but a study in longwing butterflies suggests that such hybridization could underlie the origins of a new species.
item.dc:title: Surprise hybrid origins of a butterfly species
item.dc:creator: Megan E. Frayer
Jenn M. Coughlan

item.title: An exploration of how the insect-wing hinge functions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00912-0

The hinge enables insects to control their wing movements, but how it works is hard to study. Multidisciplinary research, using imaging and machine-learning methods, now sheds light on the mechanism that underlies its operation.
item.dc:title: An exploration of how the insect-wing hinge functions
item.dc:creator: Tanvi Deora

item.title: AI traces mysterious metastatic cancers to their source
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01110-8

Algorithm examines images of metastatic cells to identify the location of the primary tumour.
item.dc:title: AI traces mysterious metastatic cancers to their source
item.dc:creator: Smriti Mallapaty

item.title: Daily briefing: Food is medicine
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01153-x

Evidence is growing that targeted dietary interventions can treat, delay and even prevent some illnesses. Plus, an AI model helps track the spread of metastatic cancers and how climate lawsuits push governments and companies to act.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Food is medicine
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: What toilets can reveal about COVID, cancer and other health threats
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01092-7

Wastewater testing grew tremendously during the pandemic. But is it ready to tackle the opioid crisis, air pollution and antibiotic resistance?
item.dc:title: What toilets can reveal about COVID, cancer and other health threats
item.dc:creator: Betsy Ladyzhets

item.title: The sympathetic nervous system arose in the earliest vertebrates
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01017-4

The sympathetic nervous system, which enables the fight-or-flight response, was thought to be present only in jawed vertebrates. Analysis of a jawless vertebrate suggests that this system might be a feature of all animals with a spine.
item.dc:title: The sympathetic nervous system arose in the earliest vertebrates
item.dc:creator: Uwe Ernsberger
Hermann Rohrer

item.title: Use game theory for climate models that really help reach net zero goals
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 April 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01083-8

Use game theory for climate models that really help reach net zero goals
item.dc:title: Use game theory for climate models that really help reach net zero goals

Raymond R. Tan
Jose B. Cruz, Jr
